description: From Old French pignon, from Latin penna (“feather”).

entries.meaning: (ornithology) The joint of a bird's wing farthest from the body.
(ornithology) Any of the outermost primary feathers on a bird's wing.
A moth of the genus Lithophane.

verbs.description: pinion (third-person singular simple present pinions, present participle pinioning, simple past and past participle pinioned) (transitive)

entries.meaning: To cut off the pinion of a bird’s wing, or otherwise disable or bind its wings, in order to prevent it from flying.
examples: They that meane to fatte Pigions…some…do softly tie their Legges:…some vse onely to pinion them.

entries.meaning: To bind the arms of someone, so as to deprive him of their use; to disable by so binding.
(transferred sense, figurative) To restrain; to limit.
examples: I am pinioned by a chain of reasoning! Why else do his four friends conspire to conceal  […]

entries.meaning: (mechanical engineering) The smallest gear in a gear train.
examples: A certain period elapses, and some unseen mysterious principle again sets in motion the magic pinions and the wizard wheels.
